NOBODY had envisaged that Bursa Malaysia would have its best run in recent years in the midst of the world battling the Coronavirus pandemic. The theme plays on glove and healthcare stocks followed by technology companies has set the local exchange on fire. The play on glove and healthcare stocks is based on the surge in demand for such materials and equipment to counter the Covid-19 virus. As for technology stocks, the theme is grounded on renewed demand for new equipment due to 5G infrastructure coming on stream. On top of that, the vacuum to be filled due to the US ban on companies supplying components to Huawei is another anchor for technology companies. This opens the doors for smaller companies in Malaysia to fulfil the needs of big tech players such as Huawei. It’s good to see that retail investors are back in droves, making up 40% of trading volumes, which hit higher than 15 billion. Many made their money from glove stocks in the early months of the bull-run that started in April this year. Their bets were on Top Glove Corp Bhd , Hartalega Holdings Bhd , Supermax Corp Bhd and Kossan Rubber Industries Holdings Bhd. It was a simple investment where one does not need a 20-page analysis to understand that a global pandemic would drive demand for gloves. In July, the focus went into the supporting players of the glove industry. Smaller producers such as Careplus Bhd and Comfort Gloves Bhd and those providing services to the glove manufacturers such as HLT Bhd and Luxchem Bhd all were hunting ground for traders seeking an opportunity to make something out of this pandemic. Trading frenzy Last Thursday, the frenzy hit a new high. In an unprecedented fashion, more than 15 stocks hit limit-up. It has never happened before on Bursa Malaysia in recent history. Volume hit 16 billion while value was less than RM5bil. The high volume but small value shows that retailers are very much in play. There are several reasons for the euphoric run on Bursa. It is primarily due to the glove sector where Bursa houses the biggest producers in the world. A contributing factor is due to Bursa and the Securities Commission having a set of lax rules to help reduce the selling pressure on stocks. The rules on short selling are put off until the end of this year. On top of that, brokers are now given more leeway on margin financing to their clients to reduce “forced selling” of counters. Previously, if the equity value falls below 130% of margin financing, brokerages are to force sell the shares. However, in March the Securities Commission allowed brokerages to exercise some discretion so that there is no discriminate force selling. The rules are good for a market that is going through an abnormal period of uncertainty. Now, that period is over. Why are the rules still in place? Many funds underperformed the market in the first half. Those which did not have any exposure to the glove sector were taken by surprise. From June onwards, the funds that underperformed the market started to play catch up, which explains why the valuations of the top four producers hit ballistic levels. The likes of Top Glove hitting as high as RM30 per share is not due to retailers. It is more likely due to the funds playing catch up to improve their performance. The funds probably have a window until the third quarter, which ends in September this year, to make up for their under-performance. In the last few months, retailers dominated the market. It is a bunch of new groups of retailers who are quick to pick up a trade. They do not use the traditional brokers and instead largely trade through online brokers such as Rakuten. Their investment decisions are based more on momentum plays. Momentum trades pay off in bullish markets. But it can be an expensive lesson when the market turns.A seasoned investor, who has been in the thick and thin of the stock market since the 1990s, recently sold his stake in Kossan. He held it for more than 12 years and was one of his core stock holdings. After he sold, the price went up further but he did not fret. The money he took off the table from glove stocks is put into other places that offered a more predictable long-term growth story. That is the art of investment. How many of the newbie traders understand the concept of trading, valuation and taking profit? How many have the discipline to take profit on their trades so that they are not “burnt” when the bullish run stops? Probably, not many understand how bad it can get if the tide turns. The market at the moment is healthy with a good combination of institutional and retail participation. But there has to be a fair amount of education that needs to be instilled so that the young investors do not get hurt badly when the tide turns. An efficient market must allow for some kind of short selling. Brokers must also be allowed to enforce the normal margin financing rules. Some say that short selling is a tool that adds liquidity to stocks, not to mention the volatility. Moreover, in Malaysia, only regulated short selling is allowed unlike in Singapore, which allows for “naked short selling”. Shouldn’t the authorities consider bringing back some of these rules that govern normal markets since the sentiments are so good? One incentive is that when such instruments are allowed, it would reduce the hive of speculation that is going on now. The new group of investors would learn to understand valuations. The sooner they understand the concept of valuation and investing, the better it is for Bursa. After the 1993 bull run, Malaysia has a breed of young investors ready to take risks. However, after the 1996 second board run and the subsequent meltdown of the local market in 1998, many lost their entire savings.Subsequently, Bursa Malaysia lost a whole generation of investors. It was because a good many who lost their entire savings were not trained to cut losses during a downturn. They did not understand the concept of valuations and economic fundamentals. They did not understand the implications of the falling ringgit to the stock market. The generation of investors who made money from the 1993 bull run never came back. Now, we have a new generation of investors who are probably exuberant. They have to learn the concept of trading and valuation. They must learn how to take money off the table and cut losses. For this to happen, the rules should be put back in place. The bumper profits of Bursa Malaysia is ample proof that the market is healthy. So why continue with the abnormal rules? The views expressed here are the writer’s own.

urn:contentItem:60WV-VS11-F0NT-H1XB-00000-00Why the ACCC is joining the fight against the 'app tax'2020-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:00ZLexisNexisWhy the ACCC is joining the fight against the 'app tax'Crikey

The app marketplace is the latest front of the global fight with big tech, and it looks like Australia's regulators may be taking up arms. This month the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) announced an inquiry into these marketplaces as part of its ongoing monitoring of platforms.  Companies like Google and Apple take up to 30% of every transaction that passes through their stores, and a back-of-the-envelope calculation suggests this big tech "tax" is costing global consumers billions of dollars each year. This is an issue that goes to the heart of the worldwide tech wars: how do you stop big tech companies positioning themselves as gatekeepers? The mandatory media code is relatively small beer: it's a squabble over the spoils of advertising between the 20th century information gatekeepers -- News Corp and Nine -- and the gatekeepers of the 21st century, Facebook and Google. But the app marketplace is about the much larger market for digital things -- mainly games, but also subscription services like Netflix and The New York Times. The Google and Apple stores give big tech access to people where they live: on their phones. And what drives almost all phones?

Google's Android and Apple's iOS. Want to reach mobile consumers with your app? Phone settings will channel them through their respective app store and usually prevent you from loading apps from other sources.  The stores started as a tool to sell smartphones, but they're now big money-makers in their own right. Even for a device-focussed company like Apple, the services business now delivers a decent chunk of its revenue. According to a Sensor Tower report (relied on by the ACCC), users of the two companies downloaded a combined 115 billion apps last year, spending a total of US$83.5 billion. The marketplace takes a cut of 30% from each transaction and pays the remaining balance to the developer. (For subscriptions, the cut drops to 15% in later years.) That means the two companies received up to US$25 billion in their respective "taxes" last year. This is a clip that sees media and entertainment caught coming and going: Google and Facebook take a chunk out of their ad revenues through ad tech (the subject of a separate ACCC inquiry) and Google and Apple take a chunk out of their subscriptions too. The big players, of course, may be able to set their own price. Amazonseems to have some agreement to sell or rent movies through the Amazon Prime app outside the Apple payment system -- although you can't buy books through the Kindle app to avoid "the Apple tax". Similarly, Netflix (which was once the largest source of app store revenues) avoids the charge by limiting in-app sign-ups, while others, like The New York Times, restrict access to discount deals in their apps. Notably, Facebook has complained about Apple taking 30% of payments for its live entertainment service through its app on iPhones when Facebook itself takes no payment. Google and Apple say their stores are just an online equivalent of traditional retail; they bring value by guaranteeing security against malware hidden in apps. Sure, say their critics, but 30% is a lot when equally security-conscious credit card companies only take a couple of percent. Apple has also been criticised for pitching its own apps, free of charge. Back in 2014, Spotify upped its price to cover the Apple tax. A year later Apple launched its matching music service, at the original lower Spotify price. Spotify opted out of the Apple payment system, requiring sign-ups through its website. Apple prevents Spotify advertising this on its app. Although the app tax is hurting media and entertainment businesses, the fight against it is being led by the gaming industry. Epic Games, owner of smash-hit Fortnite, deliberately flouted Apple and Google rules by promoting a discount for people who paid direct. It was then kicked out of both app stores and the matter is now in the courts. Australia's inquiry is being fast-tracked with a report to the treasurer due in March next year. It's an inquiry that could have real global impact -- and real benefit for Australians too.

urn:contentItem:60YJ-MF81-F0NT-H035-00000-00Why the ACCC is joining the fight against the 'app tax'2020-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:00ZLexisNexisWhy the ACCC is joining the fight against the 'app tax'Crikey

The app marketplace is the latest front of the global fight with big tech, and it looks like Australia's regulators may be taking up arms. This month the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) announced an inquiry into these marketplaces as part of its ongoing monitoring of platforms.  Companies like Google and Apple take up to 30% of every transaction that passes through their stores, and a back-of-the-envelope calculation suggests this big tech "tax" is costing global consumers billions of dollars each year. This is an issue that goes to the heart of the worldwide tech wars: how do you stop big tech companies positioning themselves as gatekeepers? The mandatory media code is relatively small beer: it's a squabble over the spoils of advertising between the 20th century information gatekeepers -- News Corp and Nine -- and the gatekeepers of the 21st century, Facebook and Google. But the app marketplace is about the much larger market for digital things -- mainly games, but also subscription services like Netflix and The New York Times. The Google and Apple stores give big tech access to people where they live: on their phones. And what drives almost all phones?

Google's Android and Apple's iOS. Want to reach mobile consumers with your app? Phone settings will channel them through their respective app store and usually prevent you from loading apps from other sources.  The stores started as a tool to sell smartphones, but they're now big money-makers in their own right. Even for a device-focussed company like Apple, the services business now delivers a decent chunk of its revenue. According to a Sensor Tower report (relied on by the ACCC), users of the two companies downloaded a combined 115 billion apps last year, spending a total of US$83.5 billion. The marketplace takes a cut of 30% from each transaction and pays the remaining balance to the developer. (For subscriptions, the cut drops to 15% in later years.) That means the two companies received up to US$25 billion in their respective "taxes" last year. This is a clip that sees media and entertainment caught coming and going: Google and Facebook take a chunk out of their ad revenues through ad tech (the subject of a separate ACCC inquiry) and Google and Apple take a chunk out of their subscriptions too. The big players, of course, may be able to set their own price. Amazonseems to have some agreement to sell or rent movies through the Amazon Prime app outside the Apple payment system -- although you can't buy books through the Kindle app to avoid "the Apple tax". Similarly, Netflix (which was once the largest source of app store revenues) avoids the charge by limiting in-app sign-ups, while others, like The New York Times, restrict access to discount deals in their apps. Notably, Facebook has complained about Apple taking 30% of payments for its live entertainment service through its app on iPhones when Facebook itself takes no payment. Google and Apple say their stores are just an online equivalent of traditional retail; they bring value by guaranteeing security against malware hidden in apps. Sure, say their critics, but 30% is a lot when equally security-conscious credit card companies only take a couple of percent. Apple has also been criticised for pitching its own apps, free of charge. Back in 2014, Spotify upped its price to cover the Apple tax. A year later Apple launched its matching music service, at the original lower Spotify price. Spotify opted out of the Apple payment system, requiring sign-ups through its website. Apple prevents Spotify advertising this on its app. Although the app tax is hurting media and entertainment businesses, the fight against it is being led by the gaming industry. Epic Games, owner of smash-hit Fortnite, deliberately flouted Apple and Google rules by promoting a discount for people who paid direct. It was then kicked out of both app stores and the matter is now in the courts. Australia's inquiry is being fast-tracked with a report to the treasurer due in March next year. It's an inquiry that could have real global impact -- and real benefit for Australians too.

urn:contentItem:60YB-N5S1-F0NT-H3WW-00000-00Why the ACCC is joining the fight against the 'app tax'2020-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:00ZLexisNexisWhy the ACCC is joining the fight against the 'app tax'Crikey

The app marketplace is the latest front of the global fight with big tech, and it looks like Australia's regulators may be taking up arms. This month the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) announced an inquiry into these marketplaces as part of its ongoing monitoring of platforms.  Companies like Google and Apple take up to 30% of every transaction that passes through their stores, and a back-of-the-envelope calculation suggests this big tech "tax" is costing global consumers billions of dollars each year. This is an issue that goes to the heart of the worldwide tech wars: how do you stop big tech companies positioning themselves as gatekeepers? The mandatory media code is relatively small beer: it's a squabble over the spoils of advertising between the 20th century information gatekeepers -- News Corp and Nine -- and the gatekeepers of the 21st century, Facebook and Google. But the app marketplace is about the much larger market for digital things -- mainly games, but also subscription services like Netflix and The New York Times. The Google and Apple stores give big tech access to people where they live: on their phones. And what drives almost all phones?

Google's Android and Apple's iOS. Want to reach mobile consumers with your app? Phone settings will channel them through their respective app store and usually prevent you from loading apps from other sources.  The stores started as a tool to sell smartphones, but they're now big money-makers in their own right. Even for a device-focussed company like Apple, the services business now delivers a decent chunk of its revenue. According to a Sensor Tower report (relied on by the ACCC), users of the two companies downloaded a combined 115 billion apps last year, spending a total of US$83.5 billion. The marketplace takes a cut of 30% from each transaction and pays the remaining balance to the developer. (For subscriptions, the cut drops to 15% in later years.) That means the two companies received up to US$25 billion in their respective "taxes" last year. This is a clip that sees media and entertainment caught coming and going: Google and Facebook take a chunk out of their ad revenues through ad tech (the subject of a separate ACCC inquiry) and Google and Apple take a chunk out of their subscriptions too. The big players, of course, may be able to set their own price. Amazonseems to have some agreement to sell or rent movies through the Amazon Prime app outside the Apple payment system -- although you can't buy books through the Kindle app to avoid "the Apple tax". Similarly, Netflix (which was once the largest source of app store revenues) avoids the charge by limiting in-app sign-ups, while others, like The New York Times, restrict access to discount deals in their apps. Notably, Facebook has complained about Apple taking 30% of payments for its live entertainment service through its app on iPhones when Facebook itself takes no payment. Google and Apple say their stores are just an online equivalent of traditional retail; they bring value by guaranteeing security against malware hidden in apps. Sure, say their critics, but 30% is a lot when equally security-conscious credit card companies only take a couple of percent. Apple has also been criticised for pitching its own apps, free of charge. Back in 2014, Spotify upped its price to cover the Apple tax. A year later Apple launched its matching music service, at the original lower Spotify price. Spotify opted out of the Apple payment system, requiring sign-ups through its website. Apple prevents Spotify advertising this on its app. Although the app tax is hurting media and entertainment businesses, the fight against it is being led by the gaming industry. Epic Games, owner of smash-hit Fortnite, deliberately flouted Apple and Google rules by promoting a discount for people who paid direct. It was then kicked out of both app stores and the matter is now in the courts. Australia's inquiry is being fast-tracked with a report to the treasurer due in March next year. It's an inquiry that could have real global impact -- and real benefit for Australians too.

urn:contentItem:60WM-WHB1-JD6R-T535-00000-00Why the ACCC is joining the fight against the 'app tax'2020-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:00ZLexisNexisWhy the ACCC is joining the fight against the 'app tax'Crikey

The app marketplace is the latest front of the global fight with big tech, and it looks like Australia's regulators may be taking up arms. This month the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) announced an inquiry into these marketplaces as part of its ongoing monitoring of platforms.  Companies like Google and Apple take up to 30% of every transaction that passes through their stores, and a back-of-the-envelope calculation suggests this big tech "tax" is costing global consumers billions of dollars each year. This is an issue that goes to the heart of the worldwide tech wars: how do you stop big tech companies positioning themselves as gatekeepers? The mandatory media code is relatively small beer: it's a squabble over the spoils of advertising between the 20th century information gatekeepers -- News Corp and Nine -- and the gatekeepers of the 21st century, Facebook and Google. But the app marketplace is about the much larger market for digital things -- mainly games, but also subscription services like Netflix and The New York Times. The Google and Apple stores give big tech access to people where they live: on their phones. And what drives almost all phones?

Google's Android and Apple's iOS. Want to reach mobile consumers with your app? Phone settings will channel them through their respective app store and usually prevent you from loading apps from other sources.  The stores started as a tool to sell smartphones, but they're now big money-makers in their own right. Even for a device-focussed company like Apple, the services business now delivers a decent chunk of its revenue. According to a Sensor Tower report (relied on by the ACCC), users of the two companies downloaded a combined 115 billion apps last year, spending a total of US$83.5 billion. The marketplace takes a cut of 30% from each transaction and pays the remaining balance to the developer. (For subscriptions, the cut drops to 15% in later years.) That means the two companies received up to US$25 billion in their respective "taxes" last year. This is a clip that sees media and entertainment caught coming and going: Google and Facebook take a chunk out of their ad revenues through ad tech (the subject of a separate ACCC inquiry) and Google and Apple take a chunk out of their subscriptions too. The big players, of course, may be able to set their own price. Amazonseems to have some agreement to sell or rent movies through the Amazon Prime app outside the Apple payment system -- although you can't buy books through the Kindle app to avoid "the Apple tax". Similarly, Netflix (which was once the largest source of app store revenues) avoids the charge by limiting in-app sign-ups, while others, like The New York Times, restrict access to discount deals in their apps. Notably, Facebook has complained about Apple taking 30% of payments for its live entertainment service through its app on iPhones when Facebook itself takes no payment. Google and Apple say their stores are just an online equivalent of traditional retail; they bring value by guaranteeing security against malware hidden in apps. Sure, say their critics, but 30% is a lot when equally security-conscious credit card companies only take a couple of percent. Apple has also been criticised for pitching its own apps, free of charge. Back in 2014, Spotify upped its price to cover the Apple tax. A year later Apple launched its matching music service, at the original lower Spotify price. Spotify opted out of the Apple payment system, requiring sign-ups through its website. Apple prevents Spotify advertising this on its app. Although the app tax is hurting media and entertainment businesses, the fight against it is being led by the gaming industry. Epic Games, owner of smash-hit Fortnite, deliberately flouted Apple and Google rules by promoting a discount for people who paid direct. It was then kicked out of both app stores and the matter is now in the courts. Australia's inquiry is being fast-tracked with a report to the treasurer due in March next year. It's an inquiry that could have real global impact -- and real benefit for Australians too.

urn:contentItem:60WN-7601-F0NT-H185-00000-00Why the ACCC is joining the fight against the 'app tax'2020-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:00ZLexisNexisWhy the ACCC is joining the fight against the 'app tax'Crikey

The app marketplace is the latest front of the global fight with big tech, and it looks like Australia's regulators may be taking up arms. This month the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) announced an inquiry into these marketplaces as part of its ongoing monitoring of platforms.  Companies like Google and Apple take up to 30% of every transaction that passes through their stores, and a back-of-the-envelope calculation suggests this big tech "tax" is costing global consumers billions of dollars each year. This is an issue that goes to the heart of the worldwide tech wars: how do you stop big tech companies positioning themselves as gatekeepers? The mandatory media code is relatively small beer: it's a squabble over the spoils of advertising between the 20th century information gatekeepers -- News Corp and Nine -- and the gatekeepers of the 21st century, Facebook and Google. But the app marketplace is about the much larger market for digital things -- mainly games, but also subscription services like Netflix and The New York Times. The Google and Apple stores give big tech access to people where they live: on their phones. And what drives almost all phones?

Google's Android and Apple's iOS. Want to reach mobile consumers with your app? Phone settings will channel them through their respective app store and usually prevent you from loading apps from other sources.  The stores started as a tool to sell smartphones, but they're now big money-makers in their own right. Even for a device-focussed company like Apple, the services business now delivers a decent chunk of its revenue. According to a Sensor Tower report (relied on by the ACCC), users of the two companies downloaded a combined 115 billion apps last year, spending a total of US$83.5 billion. The marketplace takes a cut of 30% from each transaction and pays the remaining balance to the developer. (For subscriptions, the cut drops to 15% in later years.) That means the two companies received up to US$25 billion in their respective "taxes" last year. This is a clip that sees media and entertainment caught coming and going: Google and Facebook take a chunk out of their ad revenues through ad tech (the subject of a separate ACCC inquiry) and Google and Apple take a chunk out of their subscriptions too. The big players, of course, may be able to set their own price. Amazonseems to have some agreement to sell or rent movies through the Amazon Prime app outside the Apple payment system -- although you can't buy books through the Kindle app to avoid "the Apple tax". Similarly, Netflix (which was once the largest source of app store revenues) avoids the charge by limiting in-app sign-ups, while others, like The New York Times, restrict access to discount deals in their apps. Notably, Facebook has complained about Apple taking 30% of payments for its live entertainment service through its app on iPhones when Facebook itself takes no payment. Google and Apple say their stores are just an online equivalent of traditional retail; they bring value by guaranteeing security against malware hidden in apps. Sure, say their critics, but 30% is a lot when equally security-conscious credit card companies only take a couple of percent. Apple has also been criticised for pitching its own apps, free of charge. Back in 2014, Spotify upped its price to cover the Apple tax. A year later Apple launched its matching music service, at the original lower Spotify price. Spotify opted out of the Apple payment system, requiring sign-ups through its website. Apple prevents Spotify advertising this on its app. Although the app tax is hurting media and entertainment businesses, the fight against it is being led by the gaming industry. Epic Games, owner of smash-hit Fortnite, deliberately flouted Apple and Google rules by promoting a discount for people who paid direct. It was then kicked out of both app stores and the matter is now in the courts. Australia's inquiry is being fast-tracked with a report to the treasurer due in March next year. It's an inquiry that could have real global impact -- and real benefit for Australians too.

urn:contentItem:60X8-T851-JD6R-T2FP-00000-00Why the ACCC is joining the fight against the 'app tax'2020-09-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:00ZLexisNexisWhy the ACCC is joining the fight against the 'app tax'Crikey

The app marketplace is the latest front of the global fight with big tech, and it looks like Australia's regulators may be taking up arms. This month the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) announced an inquiry into these marketplaces as part of its ongoing monitoring of platforms.  Companies like Google and Apple take up to 30% of every transaction that passes through their stores, and a back-of-the-envelope calculation suggests this big tech "tax" is costing global consumers billions of dollars each year. This is an issue that goes to the heart of the worldwide tech wars: how do you stop big tech companies positioning themselves as gatekeepers? The mandatory media code is relatively small beer: it's a squabble over the spoils of advertising between the 20th century information gatekeepers -- News Corp and Nine -- and the gatekeepers of the 21st century, Facebook and Google. But the app marketplace is about the much larger market for digital things -- mainly games, but also subscription services like Netflix and The New York Times. The Google and Apple stores give big tech access to people where they live: on their phones. And what drives almost all phones?

Google's Android and Apple's iOS. Want to reach mobile consumers with your app? Phone settings will channel them through their respective app store and usually prevent you from loading apps from other sources.  The stores started as a tool to sell smartphones, but they're now big money-makers in their own right. Even for a device-focussed company like Apple, the services business now delivers a decent chunk of its revenue. According to a Sensor Tower report (relied on by the ACCC), users of the two companies downloaded a combined 115 billion apps last year, spending a total of US$83.5 billion. The marketplace takes a cut of 30% from each transaction and pays the remaining balance to the developer. (For subscriptions, the cut drops to 15% in later years.) That means the two companies received up to US$25 billion in their respective "taxes" last year. This is a clip that sees media and entertainment caught coming and going: Google and Facebook take a chunk out of their ad revenues through ad tech (the subject of a separate ACCC inquiry) and Google and Apple take a chunk out of their subscriptions too. The big players, of course, may be able to set their own price. Amazonseems to have some agreement to sell or rent movies through the Amazon Prime app outside the Apple payment system -- although you can't buy books through the Kindle app to avoid "the Apple tax". Similarly, Netflix (which was once the largest source of app store revenues) avoids the charge by limiting in-app sign-ups, while others, like The New York Times, restrict access to discount deals in their apps. Notably, Facebook has complained about Apple taking 30% of payments for its live entertainment service through its app on iPhones when Facebook itself takes no payment. Google and Apple say their stores are just an online equivalent of traditional retail; they bring value by guaranteeing security against malware hidden in apps. Sure, say their critics, but 30% is a lot when equally security-conscious credit card companies only take a couple of percent. Apple has also been criticised for pitching its own apps, free of charge. Back in 2014, Spotify upped its price to cover the Apple tax. A year later Apple launched its matching music service, at the original lower Spotify price. Spotify opted out of the Apple payment system, requiring sign-ups through its website. Apple prevents Spotify advertising this on its app. Although the app tax is hurting media and entertainment businesses, the fight against it is being led by the gaming industry. Epic Games, owner of smash-hit Fortnite, deliberately flouted Apple and Google rules by promoting a discount for people who paid direct. It was then kicked out of both app stores and the matter is now in the courts. Australia's inquiry is being fast-tracked with a report to the treasurer due in March next year. It's an inquiry that could have real global impact -- and real benefit for Australians too.

urn:contentItem:5X6G-YGD1-F0YC-N2CH-00000-00Why the answer to a more sustainable future could lie within the platform economy2019-10-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:00ZLexisNexisWhy the answer to a more sustainable future could lie within the platform economy

Cologny: World Economic Forum has issued the following press release:

There is growing public urgency on issues such as climate change and calls for more sustainable solutions to secure a more positive future. Whilst legislators are mired in considerations of political practicality, sometimes unable to reach quick consensus on complex global issues, businesses are well-positioned, and in many cases ready, to enact effective change and fast.

While the actions and reactions of governments on sustainability issues garner much attention, businesses don’t have to wait to make real and impactful change. As many companies look to scale their sustainability efforts, there are lessons that can be learned from the proactive, agile and intrinsic approach platform businesses take when it comes to implementing widespread, effective and meaningful change.Have you read?

What the platform economy means for healthcare What are platforms and systems, and why are they so important? The 'Platform Economy' has arrived. Here's what you need to know about it

Here are just three examples of what the platform economy can teach us:1. Don’t be afraid to try new things

The ability of the platform economy to scale and react at speed is the reason Big Tech sits at the top of the leader board across the world’s stock markets. It’s also a capability that’s well suited to tackling urgent global issues by introducing new approaches and innovative concepts.

The instinctively innovative and entrepreneurial nature of platform companies means they are great test beds for new ideas and initiatives. They are well placed to be a force for good and can easily drive new sustainable solutions and ideas as part of normal business development.

Platform businesses often don’t hesitate to try new things and we see them proactively testing new sustainable solutions and processes, often before they are asked to by policy-makers. Where these tests result in success, the nature of platforms means that solutions can be scaled quickly across the business.

Great recent examples include initiatives from Deliveroo, which has trialled and scaled its “opt for cutlery” feature following its quick success, while Rent the Runway has introduced environmentally-friendly dry cleaning processes across its whole business, going further than the standards set by regulators.

By adopting the entrepreneurial mindset of a platform business and not being afraid to trial new things, all businesses have the ability to take the lead in finding new solutions and help us save precious time in delivering and securing a more sustainable future.2. Make sustainability part of who you are

Businesses are increasingly focusing on the relationship between sustainability and long-term corporate health. As platforms have emerged, so has a new, ingrained culture and positive attitude towards sustainability. For many platform companies, sustainability has been a consideration from day one and is part of their DNA. It is embedded in their brand, operations - and often expected by their customers (regardless of the product or the service).

Making sustainability an inherent part of who you are, not just something you do, as platform businesses have done, means that businesses can ensure sustainability is a consideration at all points. Platforms have shown us how making sustainability a part of every decision, action and conversation can expand the positive impact a business can have, without creating a burden.

More traditional companies are often working to reactively copy and retro-fit approaches to sustainability. They have been slower to recognise the impact of day-to-day operations from a sustainability perspective. Packaging, where plastics and other unsustainable materials have featured heavily, and waste disposal, which revolved around landfill or disposal through incineration for a long time, are prime examples of this.

Broadly speaking, traditional businesses have been more financially-driven in their approach than the more modern platform companies we see coming through. But they are increasingly realising that the investor community is not the only community that must be considered when it comes to business models and operations - consumers and policy-makers matter, too.3. Collaborate and connect

A crucial advantage of the platform economy is its unparalleled connectivity. A web of global customers, commercial partnerships and collaborations with other technology firms – from start-ups to multinationals – allows organizations to rapidly disseminate their ideas, policies and solutions, and call on a broad base of expertise, knowledge and resources.

One of my favourite examples of this is the collaboration between eBay, Google, Facebook and leading animal welfare charities to help reduce the black market trade for prohibited products such as ivory, where simply outlawing the practice hasn’t worked so far.IndiaWhat is the World Economic Forum's India Economic Summit 2019?

Under the theme, Innovating for India: Strengthening South Asia, Impacting the World, the World Economic Forum's India Economic Summit 2019 will convene key leaders from government, the private sector, academia and civil society on 3-4 October to accelerate the adoption of Fourth Industrial Revolution technologies and boost the region’s dynamism.

Hosted in collaboration with the Confederation of Indian Industry (CII), the aim of the Summit is to enhance global growth by promoting collaboration among South Asian countries and the ASEAN economic bloc.

The meeting will address strategic issues of regional significance under four thematic pillars:

• The New Geopolitical Reality – Geopolitical shifts and the complexity of our global system

• The New Social System – Inequality, inclusive growth, health and nutrition

• The New Ecological System – Environment, pollution and climate change

• The New Technological System – The Fourth Industrial Revolution, science, innovation and entrepreneurship

Discover a few ways the Forum is creating impact across India.

Read our guide to how to follow #ies19 across our digital channels. We encourage followers to post, share, and retweet by tagging our accounts and by using our official hashtag.

Become a Member or Partner to participate in the Forum's year-round annual and regional events. Contact us now.

In the travel industry, platforms like Booking.com are well placed to foster such collaboration. I have seen first-hand how it can bring forward innovative and collective solutions. The recently launched Travlyst Programme, a global initiative founded by Booking.com, Ctrip, Skyscanner, TripAdvisor and Visa with the ambition to change the impact of travel for good, is a great example of how platforms, businesses and thought leaders are coming together to protect and promote a positive future for travellers, destinations and local communities alike.

Whether it’s a bold approach to trying new things, working collaboratively or refocusing the corporate culture to help embed sustainability in the day-to-day, there is plenty that can be done to help us secure a more positive future - and platform businesses can show us the way.

urn:contentItem:60TY-2661-F0J6-J029-00000-00Why the big tech gorillas will submit to wrestled revenue deal2020-09-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:00ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 35Why the big tech gorillas will submit to wrestled revenue dealRichard Alston

Digital platforms Facebook and Google will prefer an arbitrated outcome under our world-first news media code to avoid setting a more damaging international precedent.

The federal government's recent decision to mandate a news media bargaining code has been a long time coming but is still a trailblazing experiment whose outcome will be watched around the world.

The decision has already been met with a hysterical response from big tech and its allies, but this is little more than par for the course. Despite the bluster, it's likely big tech will prefer a forced arbitrated outcome under the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission's pioneering code. This outcome could then be portrayed as a one-off result of regulatory duress.

In comparison, the alternative - a negotiated revenue-sharing deal with traditional media - would set a more damaging and costly international precedent.

So far, and predictably, there's been little or no response from big tech on the merits of the argument. The main line of argument seems to be the leviathans don't make much money out of aggregating and publishing the news of others, so it would not be a big deal to simply close it down. This is almost certainly disingenuous.

As well as depriving their multitude of users of ready access to quality journalism, it would enable disinformation and conspiracy theories to flourish - hardly a good look. The Australian Communications and Media Authority has established that there are significant public concerns about misinformation on digital platforms - a key source of news and information for many Australians. Hence the authority has concluded the digital platforms should share considerable responsibility for providing readers with a safe and

user-friendly environment in which to digest news and information.

Despite the fury, Facebook has said it is still committed to supporting Australian news. But it is not the decision to introduce new disclosure standards and higher levels of accountability that is big tech's real concern; rather it is the decision to force them to share advertising revenue that has Facebook and Google up in arms.

It has become increasingly clear in recent years that the high-tech new entrants are eating into the revenue of traditional media players, leading to a serious crisis of survival for many.

A mandatory code was the inevitable next step when it became clear that voluntary negotiations on a fair price for the digital platforms' aggregation and dissemination of the creative work of news creators and publishers were going nowhere. The ACCC calculates that Google and Facebook take more than two-thirds of digital advertising revenue. Normally the creators of innovative material reap the bulk of the rewards, but in this case it's the distributors who get the lion's share.

This is precisely because of the grotesque imbalance in bargaining power between trillion-dollar tech companies going from strength to strength, and traditional media companies going out backwards. Content creation is a lot more difficult and more expensive than aggregation and distribution.

Facebook pays some media for news content, so the principle has already been established - even though such payments are made essentially on a discretionary basis, given the very one-sided power imbalance.

Henry Kissinger always regarded leverage as a key element in successful negotiations and, as Donald Trump's The Art of the Deal makes clear, to strike a good bargain you need bargaining power.

That's why the ACCC's implied threat to impose a blanket 10 per cent tax on digital revenue is an important weapon in the fight, as such an impost would be a horror outcome for big tech. This makes it highly likely they will come to the table, especially as there will be substantial penalties for not engaging in negotiations.

The relatively new concept of final-offer arbitration should also help to concentrate the mind. Under this model the tribunal is obliged to render an award by selecting in its entirety one of the parties' final proposal. The arbitrator cannot split the difference, as decision makers are often inclined to do. This raises the stakes, as each party faces the prospect of losing its entire case and is therefore motivated to make a more realistic proposal. Normally in a commercial negotiation affordability is an important factor. However, when dealing with the big tech companies, capacity to pay is not an issue. What concerns the digital platforms much more is the knock-on effect in other jurisdictions, where a reasonable compromise in one country simply becomes the starting point for negotiations in others.

The ACCC recently signed an arrangement with fellow regulators in the Anglosphere to co-ordinate activities in dealing with anti-competitive issues. In the same way, counterparties in other countries that have to deal with big tech would be immediately aware of the market opportunity that would arise from a negotiated settlement in Australia.

This makes it more likely that big tech would prefer an arbitrated outcome, which they can then argue is simply a one-off and not a product of their preparedness to compromise elsewhere.

The stakes are high, and not just for the players involved. All Australians have a vital interest in having ready access to a diversity of high-quality, accurate and reliable news and information services. This race has a long way to run.

Richard Alston was federal communications minister from 1996 to 2003 and is chairman of National Advisory.

urn:contentItem:6053-N221-DY1R-B2JG-00000-00Why the coronavirus pandemic is a great opportunity for big tech companies2020-06-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:00ZLexisNexisWhy the coronavirus pandemic is a great opportunity for big tech companies


Telework, telemedicine, school and even birthdays remotely, contact tracking of infected people, database of available hospital supplies: technology has played a key role in the reordering of daily life disrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic. If since its inception the industry had been set out as an indispensable revolution—and its founders saw its creatures as essential, and essentially good—the coronavirus suddenly restored that status of public service to which it always aspired.


They thus reflected the visions promoted by the original slogans, such as "making the world a more open and connected place" (Facebook), and pushed into the past the hard-learned lessons such as the Cambridge Analytica affair: the use, without consent, of data of millions of people.
Misinformation, political manipulation, control of people (as consumers and as citizens), destruction of traditional media and businesses: all this stopped mattering because Google Meet kept children in school, Zoom saved jobs, Doxy allowed to consult doctors and Amazon Fresh filled the fridge with those who could stay at home and avoid SARS-CoV-2.
Telemedicine has seen massive growth during the pandemic. (Shutterstock)
Not only did these companies maintain their profits while the rest of the world's economy fell apart: "As governments faltered in their responses to the pandemic, the great technology have presented the act as a charitable friend, willing to lend a competent hand," Franklin Foer wrote in his analysis for The Atlantic. And he quoted a disturbing phrase from Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella:
"The challenges we face demand an unprecedented alliance between businesses and the government."
Nadella said that in April, the same month google and Apple announced that they would suspend their rivalries to cooperate with each other and with different countries around the world to pause their incompatibility and cooperate in tracking contacts of people infected with the coronavirus. In several U.S. states, which have been unable to process the barrage of unemployment subsidy orders, Amazon and Google intervened to strengthen the systems. As Nadella added, "At Microsoft we see ourselves as digital lifeguards."
All very nice, Foer reflected, "but not enough reason to put on hold the skepticism before the tech industry that tries to take advantage of this moment." With unprecedented influence, a huge ability to manipulate public opinion and shape markets, Big Tech does not want to supplant governments, but something less desirable: "They've basically sought to merge with them," he warned.
Education, usually a state affair, now has technology as a partner. (MOISÉUS PABLO/FOURTH) (Moses Paul/)
And since before the pandemic, recalled the author of World Without Mind. Now they only find a formidable opportunity.
In the early days of the computer revolution, young companies saw in the states an anti-innovation caste, with their regulations restricting the future. Even in 2016 Apple refused to unlock the iPhone of a dead terrorist to cooperate with the investigation, as an "excessive interference" in privacy that guarantees its customers. But in maturity, after the setbacks Microsoft suffered for monopoly, something that could also be seen on Amazon, and after the scandals of the 2016 US presidential campaign, companies can no longer fake the candor of a startup.
Mark Zuckerberg himself, founder and CEO of Facebook, said in his presentation to the US Senate in 2018: "I think the real question, as the internet becomes more important in people's lives, is what the right regulation is, not whether or not there should be some regulation."
Contact tracking applications when a coronavirus contagiote is detected are used in at least 27 countries. (REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach) (Kai Pfaffenbach/)
According to The Atlantic's analysis, Zuckerberg thus recognized the spirit of the time: by then large tech companies were synonymous with misinformation, private data commerce and even mental health problems among adolescents. And in doing that recognition, at the same time, he placed himself in the front row to influence that establishment of standards. "Last year Facebook spent about $17 million on lobbying, more than any other company. The same logic caused Amazon to locate its second power plant near the Potomac River," that is, near the Capitol, "and led companies like Google and Microsoft to build relationships with the intelligence community."
Foer added: "The eminences of these companies are part of the official councils that advise the government on how to improve their computer skills. It's telling that the most unpleasant domestic fight between technology companies is for a $10 billion cloud services contract with the Department of Defense."
The pandemic came to reinforce this relationship between industry and governments. The U.S., for example, wants kits for COVID-19 analysis but can't get enough: "As the country expects a vaccine, the government might have no choice but to rely on big technology to make up its gaps in capacity and knowledge."
Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg told the US Senate: "The real question, as the internet becomes more important in people's lives, is what the right regulation is, not whether or not there should be any regulation."
These alliances have not been virtuous, historically, Foer warned: "China's technology industry helped build a state of advanced surveillance, beyond what it wasimaginable for George Orwell. Technology companies practice the science of exploiting data in order to alter human behavior—ideal for a state eager to forge the loyalty of its people." As an example, he cited China's "social credit" system, which ratreas and rates certain people's acts: "That is the basis of rewards and punishments. A citizen may lose the right to travel if he is caught crossing the street where it shouldn't be or if he puts the music very loud."
While the U.S. mode of government would not allow such a thing, the article noted the potential consequences of the big tech-government merger. And he pointed to the learnings that left past crises in which a collective atmosphere of anguish and trauma was created.
"A year before September 11, 2001, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) issued a report recommending vigorous legislation restricting the business use of online data, which would have included the right to correct (or delete) personal information," he recalled. "But the terrorist attacks altered the calculation. Security was prioritized over any other consideration: the country quickly became accustomed to ubiquitous CCTV cameras, body scans at airports, and a remarkable extension of powers to untransparent government offices."
China's technology industry helped build Beijing's state of advanced surveillance. (Photo: Special)
Because of the COVID-19 crisis, at least 27 countries began using cell phone data to track transmission. Among them are some evidence of NSO's Fleming software, an Israeli firm that Amnesty International accused of creating spy apps to monitor human rights activists.
Google and Apple, for now, have "tried to set the terms of society" with governments, "instead of giving them the data it craves." The design of the COVID-19 alert system prevents centralized data collection and has an expiration date when the pandemic ends, they said. But it will be a matter of time, Foer said, that Google and Apple face "increasing pressure to monitor COVID-19 patients as closely as they follow those who use their maps."
Big tech companies and governments could give in to the temptation of "their worst shared instincts." Especially in the United States, where there is no Data Protection Agency as in Europe. More than 300 scientists and academics signed a letter warning that "some 'solutions' to the crisis could allow unprecedented vigilance of society as a whole."

urn:contentItem:5G96-7K01-DY9P-N3PC-00000-00Why the Irish regulator is listened to abroad2015-06-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:00ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 7Why the Irish regulator is listened to abroad

THE Commissioner's annual report now attracts global interest as media and tech firms look for signs around what Europe's most influential data regulator might do next. Within minutes of the annual report's publication this week, media organisations such as Bloomberg and 'The New York Times' were flashing headlines and dissecting some of the report's main points The reason is simple. Positions that the Portarlington-based office take have far-reaching implications for some of the world's biggest companies, such as Apple, Google and Facebook.

It is why most big web companies now consult with the Irish office before rolling out major new global features. If a new service or feature gets a thumbs down from the Irish regulator, a company like Facebook or Apple can't release it. Apple "proactively" consulted the Irish office before launching map-enhancing photo-vehicles around the streets of Ireland and the UK. Facebook's updated terms and conditions, released earlier this year, are also influenced by this process.

For the most part, big tech companies like the regulator's approach. This is what Facebook's director of public policy Richard Allan said recently about why the social media giant prefers dealing with the Irish office.

"They provide advice and guidance, that means that we fix things so that they don't have to bring out the big stick," said Allan. "We're not scared to go and see them because they will drag us into court the next day. If they were merely a 'big stick' regulator, frankly, we would be incentivised not to take things to them."

Facebook's experience is not unique. US companies are now actively choosing Ireland as a data regulation home in Europe. "A lot of US firms think that Europe is over the top when it comes to data protection, but they like the approach that Ireland takes and this is why many choose to be regulated here," said John Whelan, head of the A&L Goodbody's Silicon Valley office.

"The amicable resolution approach that the Irish data protection office has is very attractive to US companies. The Irish office has huge regard within Silicon Valley. It's one of the reasons that companies are choosing to be regulated here."

The flipside is scepticism and cynicism from other commentators. "Of course Facebook would go to a country with the lowest levels of data protection," sneered former German federal data protection commissioner, Peter Schaar recently. "It's natural they would choose Ireland."

Critics say the Irish office has been underfunded, a charge that Helen Dixon partially acknowledges. She says, however, that the office's funding is increasing almost two-fold this year.

Dixon also says that some of the criticism stems from a difference in opinion over styles of enforcement.

"There are those that disagree with [our 'engagement'] approach, and there are discussions afoot about the underlying framework of data protection in Europe," she said. "But with the framework and the facts as they are, I am confident that the engaged approach used by my 0ffice is the right one, and that our expanded resources and geographic proximity to decision-makers in leading technology companies make us well-placed to regulate with the full efficacy that our stakeholders deserve."

urn:contentItem:5TDX-6XN1-JCBJ-K0V6-00000-00WHY THE MILITARY MUST LEARN TO LOVE SILICON VALLEY: THE U.S. DEFENSE DEPARTMENT AND BIG TECH NEED EACH OTHER--BUT GETTING ALONG WON'T BE EASY.2018-09-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:00ZLexisNexisPg. 50WHY THE MILITARY MUST LEARN TO LOVE SILICON VALLEY: THE U.S. DEFENSE DEPARTMENT AND BIG TECH NEED EACH OTHER--BUT GETTING ALONG WON'T BE EASY.Seligman, Lara

PEOPLE WHO FORM THEIR IDEAS about the U.S. military based on Hollywood movies might get the impression that cutting-edge technology is standard in the fighting forces. In fact, the opposite is true. At nuclear sites around the country, technicians still use floppy disks. Only this summer is the U.S. Navy expected to upgrade from Windows XP, an operating system long since scrubbed from home computers. The new F-35 stealth fighter jet, touted as the most sophisticated in the world, was first conceived of in the 1990s.

So when the Defense Department announced last year that it wanted to partner with Silicon Valley to build a massive cloud storage unit where it could securely warehouse and categorize the secret data it collects from intelligence agencies and the military, some experts scoffed. Companies such as Amazon and Google are defined by an ethos of agility and innovation. The Pentagon, by contrast, is known to be clunky and risk averse. Just getting a contract through the department's famously byzantine procurement process would require a kind of bureaucratic wrangling that a Jeff Bezos or a Tim Cook would find abhorrent.

Yet the Defense Department's effort to advance the cloud project is making slow progress. The grueling process has revealed all the ways in which the two sides in the partnership are fundamentally incompatible. But it has also forced the Pentagon to confront a sobering truth: If it hopes to maintain U.S. military dominance, it must make such partnerships work. The imperative is bound up with the way technological innovation has shifted over the past few decades from government-funded labs around the country to commercial companies. It's also tied to some broader changes in the world, including the rise of China as a great power.

The fact that the U.S. government pioneered many of the great technological breakthroughs of the 20th century has become common knowledge. The internet began decades ago as a computer networking project in the offices of the Advanced Research Projects Agency--essentially a Defense Department incubator. The satellite navigation systems that now feature on most smartphones were hatched in the same place.

But starting in the 1990s, as military budgets declined and investment in tech companies soared, the private sector gained a huge advantage in innovation. Most tech firms have focused on producing consumer goods. But some of the technology they've developed, if applied to the military, could transform the way war is waged.

U.S. Defense Secretary James Maitis, for one, appears to be well aware of this fact (though his service on the board of the failed tech company Theranos didn't exactly burnish his credentials in Silicon Valley). The Pentagon's latest National Defense Strategy identifies eight technologies the military wants to leverage for its own advantage, including advanced computing, big data analytics, artificial intelligence, and robotics. "Success does not go to the country that develops a new technology first but rather to the one that better integrates it and more swiftly adapts its way of fighting," Mattis said when the strategy was unveiled in January.

What stood out about his list was the fact that the commercial sector is largely driving six of the eight technologies on it, according to Robert Work, who served as the deputy defense secretary until last year. Work was one of the Pentagon's main proponents of partnerships with the commercial sector. More than most of his colleagues, he understood the challenges of bridging the culture gap between the two sides.

To try to do so, three years ago Work helped set up the Defense Innovation Unit Experimental, or DIUx, a kind of Pentagon outpost in Silicon Valley that was meant to serve as a liaison between the Defense Department and the tech world. (In August, DIUx shortened its name to DIU, on the grounds that it was no longer experimental.) Though it scored some successes early on--the Pentagon expanded the program to Boston and Austin--it has started to lose steam since the departure of its managing director, Raj Shah, this year. Still, Work believes that the Pentagon has already learned some valuable lessons from the experience.

Last year, when he was still in office, Work launched Project Maven, one of the Pentagon's deepest forays to date into the high-tech realm. The program makes use of AI to analyze huge amounts of drone data--a painstaking process traditionally handled by humans. Project Maven aims to eventually replace and improve on much of that work, identifying threats, tracking enemy movements, and detecting anomalies that the human eye may overlook. "I remain convinced that we need to do much more, and move much faster, across DoD to take advantage of recent and future advances in these critical areas," Work wrote in an April 2017 memo.

Project Maven is already operating in at least five secret locations in the Middle East and Africa. But it has hit some snags. This April, more than 3,000 employees at Google signed a letter protesting the company's involvement in the project on the grounds that "Google should not be in the business of war." The company responded by vowing not to renew the partnership when it expires next year. Still, the Pentagon's investment in AI and Project Maven continues as other tech companies find these lucrative contracts hard to resist.

Building on Maven's success would require the Defense Department to consolidate its data, including the information it gets from surveillance drones and from the military intelligence community, and label it in a machine-readable format. To that end, in July the Pentagon launched an enormous tender for a cloud storage contract, code-named JEDI (Joint Enterprise Defense Infrastructure). In both the Pentagon and Silicon Valley, JEDI's success--or failure--is being watched as a test case for whether the two cultures can cooperate.

Should it succeed, the program will offer significant advantages for both the government and the commercial sector. The contract is estimated to be worth $10 billion, making it a huge prize for even the biggest firms. The company that wins JEDI, a two-year contract with an option for more work thereafter, would also get a leg up in securing other Pentagon deals--including filling the department's further needs for cloud storage. As for the Defense Department, the project would allow for faster and deeper analysis of its intelligence data. "The road to AI begins with a lot of banal, boring steps that sound like putting in a telephone system and archiving and databasing, but that is the work we have to do," said Will Roper, the U.S. Air Force's top acquisition official and formerly head of the Pentagon's secretive Strategic Capabilities Office.

Critical as it is, the initiative has been bogged down by the Defense Department's antiquated acquisition system. It took officials until late July to release the final request for proposals, and it's not clear when the contract will be awarded. During a May 31 press conference, Pentagon spokeswoman Dana White declined to commit to a timeline. "We are working on it, but it's important that we don't rush toward failure," she said. "We also want to take in all of the different stakeholders and consider how we move best forward."

The Pentagon wants to avoid a situation where one or more of the bidders protests the results of the contracting process, which is one reason it's moving carefully--and slowly. Most analysts assume that Amazon is the front-runner--in part because it is among the world's largest cloud services providers and already works with the U.S. intelligence community on other projects. But a coalition of tech companies from Microsoft to Red Hat is reportedly coordinating efforts to keep the JEDI contract from going exclusively to Amazon. Google was considering making a bid as well, though the decision to pull out of Project Maven may complicate the issue. "Amazon sort of feels like the Lebron James of this field," said Daniel Goure, the senior vice president of the Lexington Institute, a public policy think tank that focuses on security-related issues.

The tender process was supposed to be the easy part. Once the Pentagon chooses a contractor for JEDI, the winner will have to meet the government's many regulatory requirements, particularly in the area of cybersecurity. Frank Kendall, the Pentagon's top acquisition official until 2017, said the commercial world does not fully understand these obscure demands. "I would just urge a bit of caution," he said. "I think people rushing headlong into embracing some of these commercial firms--they need to be a little more careful."

As a cautionary example, Kendall pointed to the intelligence community's effort to migrate to the commercial cloud. Since 2014, the CIA and the 16 other U.S. intelligence agencies have been working to shift top-secret and classified information onto Amazon's cloud. Though some CIA officials tout the move as transformational, Kendall said implementation has been "slower than expected" due to cybersecurity concerns and the Pentagon's stringent regulatory process.

To be sure, whenever the Pentagon contracts with outside companies, the process tends to be painstaking and time-consuming. The production of the F-35, Lockheed Martin's latest fighter jet, underscores that point. Originally planned to be deployed starting in 2010, the stealth fighter suffered years of delays, cost overruns, and technical challenges. The Air Force only declared the aircraft ready for deployment in 2016.

Given the rapid technological advances being made by potential U.S. adversaries, particularly China, however, the U.S. military can't afford similar delays in JEDI and other high-tech partnerships. Today, three of the world's five most valuable tech startups are Chinese, and companies such as Baidu, Alibaba, Tencent, and Huawei are narrowing the research and development spending gap with their U.S. competitors, according to the Council on Foreign Relations. Unlike Washington, moreover, authoritarian powers have an easy time working with local tech firms: They simply tell them what to do. That's one of the reasons that Eric Schmidt, the former chairman of Alphabet (Google's parent company) and the chairman of the Defense Innovation Board, recently warned that China was poised to surpass the United States in the AI race by 2025.

"We are now in a big technological competition with great powers," Work said. "We cannot assume that our technological superiority is a given. We are going to have to fight for it."

urn:contentItem:5WC9-6341-F0J6-J4S9-00000-00Why the social network is turning to cryptocurrency;Comment2019-06-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:47:00ZLexisNexisCOMPANIES AND MARKETSPg. 21Why the social network is turning to cryptocurrencyCommentJohn Davidson

Facebook's entry into cryptocurrency needs to be seen in the context of its pivot away from social media, and towards private, person-to-person communication, which it is hoping to dominate with a suite of software and services that will soon include person-to-person payments.

"Pivot" is probably not a strong enough word for the transformation Facebook is attempting, as it tries to distance itself from the scandals and social opprobrium that have engulfed its social media platform.

The move from public social networks, where Facebook made its billions, towards private, secure connections where people will be able to swap stories and, now, swap money with each other, is closer to a "repudiation" than a mere "pivot".

Contrast what Facebook's founder, Mark Zuckerberg, said about the need for private communications in 2010, when the corporate motto was "Move Fast And Break Things" - "People have really gotten comfortable not only sharing more information and different kinds, but more openly and with more people.

"That social norm is just something that has evolved over time" - with what he said in April this year, standing in front of a banner that read "The Future Is Private":

"Over time, I believe that a private social platform will be even more important to our lives than our digital town squares."

Or with what he wrote in a blog posting in March, announcing the pivot/repudiation: "As I think about the future of the internet, I believe a privacy-focused communications platform will become even more important than today's open platforms ... Today we already see that private messaging, ephemeral stories, and small groups are by far the fastest growing areas of online communication."

Social media as we know it, in short, is a failed experiment. The world is moving on, and Facebook is trying to move with it.

Even Jack Dorsey, the controversial co-founder and CEO of that other social media company Twitter, has acknowledged the failure of social media, embarking this year on what has amounted to a prolonged apology tour where he's been long on self-loathing but short on self-improvement (perhaps because there is no easy way to fix social media: handing a megaphone to every nutter on the planet was never going to end well).

"I also don't feel good about how Twitter tends to incentivise outrage, fast takes, short term thinking, echo chambers, and fragmented conversation and consideration," Mr Dorsey tweeted, in just one of many mea culpas.

But not feeling good about the mess one has made in the world, and wishing to distance oneself from it, is not the same thing as successfully putting the past behind you.

Such is the damage Facebook's social media platform has done âˆ’ privacy scandals, election scandals, ethnic-cleansing scandals, live-streaming the mass murder of New Zealanders, to name just the recent outrages âˆ’ that lawmakers around the world are baying for blood. Facebook's move into creating a digital currency that would need regulatory approval, and yet compete with fiat currency, needs to be seen in the context of that, too.

It needs to be seen in the context of anti-trust investigations into big tech, that seem more disposed to break up tech companies such as Facebook, than allow them to increase in size and market power.

And besides, is now really the best time for a reputationally on the nose company such as Facebook to be asking regulators to trust it?

Or should regulators wait until the pivot/repudiation is complete, so they know exactly which Facebook they're dealing with? The one that moves fast and breaks things, or one that actually cares about the security and privacy required to manage a new currency?
